markdown:
<title
    level="1"
    right="Weapon 0"
    pfs="Standard"
>
[Whip Claw](/Weapons.aspx?ID=482)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Uncommon" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=721" />
<trait label="Catfolk" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=746" />
<trait label="Finesse" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=602" />
<trait label="Hampering" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=806" />
<trait label="Reach" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=684" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

**Source** [Player Core 2](/Sources.aspx?ID=227) pg. 275 <sup>1.1</sup>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 5 gp

**Damage** 1d6 S

**Bulk** 1
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Hands** 2

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Type** Melee

**Category** Advanced

**Group** [Flail](/WeaponGroups.aspx?ID=7)
</row>

</column>

---

The whip claw is a long tether affixed to claw-like daggers, allowing the wielder to fling and retract them with deadly precision. Catfolk first developed this weapon to provide extended reach when hunting dangerous animals, and they wield them with unmatched expertise.

<title level="2">Critical Specialization Effects</title>

**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 283 <sup>4.0</sup>

Certain feats, class features, weapon runes, and other effects can grant you additional benefits when you make a Strike with certain weapons and get a critical success. This is called a critical specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which weapon group your weapon belongs to, as listed below. You can always decide not to add the critical specialization effect of your weapon.

[Click here for the full rules on Critical Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=235).

<document level="2" id="weapon-group-7" />
name: Whip Claw
